cab.content: The annexed tables show the acreage, yield per acre and total produce of the wheat, oat, potato and turnip crops in Scotland in 1916, with corresponding estimates for 1917.The data for these estimates are, however, so uncertain that the figures are submitted with very great reserve.(1) As regards acreage, returns have been received from twenty-five of the counties indicating with more or less com-pleteness the additional area intended to be cropped. Even, however, if the returns were complete, they could not be taken unconditionally, as several reports state that the recent re-currence of severe weather has made it doubtful whether the intentions of farmers can be carried outiFurther, the reports do not in all cases indicate the distribution of the additional acreage among the various crops; this distribution has therefore had to be roughly estimated.In cases where no reports are as yet available, a rough estimate has been made of the probable increase, if any.It should however be observed that (except in the case of wheat) no account is taken of a.ny decrease of acreage due to land being left in grass that would normally have been broken up. Thus the increased acreage shown in the tables cannot be taken with certainty as a net increase-(2) As regards the estimated yield per acre, it is of course impossible to make a forecast without taking into account the accidents of weather, the incidence of disease and otherinfluences, and the only basis that can be adopted is thei /i I *\average of the last ten years. iCnAx^IThe / The following observations are made regarding each crop:-WHEAT: In very few cases has a definite increase in acreage been reported by the District Committees. Eeports have however been received from the Board's Crop Reporters indicating the probable increase or decrease of acreage in each county.The acreage and produce in recent years were as follows:-1912. 1913. 1914. 1915. 1916.Acreage......---- 62,400 54,800 60,500 76,600 63,000Produce (Quarters) 300,000 283,000 320,000 370,000 283,000The marked increase in acreage in 1915 was not maintained in 1916. The estimated acreage this year is 58,400, showing a decrease of 4,7 00 acres as compared with last year. Should the yield be normal, the total produce will be 292,000 quarters, or 9000 more than last year.BARLEY; Ho definite evidence is available as to changes in acreage this year, and the factors determining the acreage are so uncertain that no estimate Is offered.The acreage and produce in recent years were as follows:-1912. 1913. 1914. 1915. 1916.Acreage........... 192,000 198,000 194,000 149,000 17 0,000Produce (Quarters) 862,000 921,000 923,000" 628,000 647,000The great decrease in acreage in 1915 was in 1916 made up to the extent of nearly one-half.Should the acreage this year remain unchanged, and should the yield per acre be equal to the decennial average, 36 bushels, the total produce would be 765,000 quarters, showing an increase of 118,000 quarters.OATS; By far the greater proportion of the increased acreage reported is assigned to oats.The acreage and produce in recent years were as follows:-1912. 1913. 1914. 1915. 1916.Acreage........... 957,000 938,000 920,000 983,000 991,000Produce (Quarters) 4596,000 4502,000 4619,000 4885,000 4528,000There was thus a very substantial increase in 1915 and 1916 over the acreage in 1914, which was the smallest on record.The estimate for 1917 shows a further increase of 47,000 acres, raising the acreage to over a million for the first time for many years.The estimated produce, 4,860,000 quarters, shows an increase of about 330,000 quarters as compared with 1916.POTATOES:/ POTATOES: The estimates in this case are probably still more uncertain than those for wheat and oats.Practically all the balance cf the increased acreage reported is assigned to potatoes.The acreage and produce in recent years were as follows:-1912. 1913. 1914. 1915. 1916.Acreage........... 150,000 149,000 152,000 144,000 130,000Produce (Tons)---- 939,000 971,000 1078,000 972,000 531,000The estimate for 1917 shows an increase of about 10,000 acres, bringing the acreage nearly up to the level of 1915.The estimated produce, 910,000 tons, shows an increase of about 380,000 tons as compared with 1916.If the acreage could be raised to the level of the years 1912 to 1914 - 150,000 acres, the produce would be 97 5,000 tons.TURNIPS and Sf^ES: Very few definite statements of increased acreage have been received, and in most cases a round figure has been set down for this yearns acreage, which in some cases involves an increase and in others a decrease as compared with 1916.The acreage and produce in recent years were as follows:-1912. 1913* 1914. 1915. 1916.Acreage........... 440,000 432,000 431,000 421,000 414,000Produce (Tons)---- 7390,000 7 330,000 6310,000 7 530,000 5900,000The estimate for 1917 shows an increa.se of 2000 acres.Should the yield be equal to the decennial average, the produce would be nearly 7,000,000 tons, or over a million tons more than last year. Should the acreage be raised to the average of the years 1912 to 1915 the yield might then be estimated at 7,250,000 tons.
